description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.

Whether you're new to Agile or a veteran,

And, of course, I've got Miss Jo Peacock
with us to explain what we should expect.

5

6

>> Absolutely great, thank you, Cherokee.

7
00:00:20.580 --> 00:00:24.980
And in this series, what we're going
to be looking at is Agile texting,

8

9

We're really building on
all of the information,

10
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:33.450
all of the skills that you learned
in your Agile fundamental series.

11
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:38.710
And we're just gonna be looking at how
testing happens in an Agile project.

12
00:00:38.710 --> 00:00:40.435
There's a lot of sort of, well,

13
00:00:40.435 --> 00:00:44.230
misconception that testing doesn't
happen in our job project.

14
00:00:44.230 --> 00:00:47.930
And that's not true, so we're gonna
be looking at testing quadrants,

15

we're gonna be looking at what we test,
the types of tests.

16
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:54.100
And we're also going to be
looking at who should test, and

17

we're even gonna spend a little
bit of time talking about uses and

18
00:00:57.580 --> 00:00:59.520
what their involvement should be as well.

19
00:00:59.520 --> 00:01:00.914
>> Great Jo, thanks so much and

20
00:01:00.914 --> 00:01:04.471
if that sounds like something you're
interested in, then stay tuned.

21
00:01:04.471 --> 00:01:10.401
[MUSIC]

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.317
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.317 --> 00:00:01.971
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.971 --> 00:00:05.337
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.337 --> 00:00:08.263
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.263 --> 00:00:11.835
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.835 --> 00:00:14.056
>> Welcome, everyone,
to your Agile testing series.

7
00:00:14.056 --> 00:00:16.850
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:20.250
In this episode, we'll be taking
a look at an intro to Agile.

9
00:00:20.250 --> 00:00:22.760
And with us today in studios we have Mrs.
Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:22.760 --> 00:00:24.040
How's it going today, Jo?

11
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:24.960
>> Absolutely great.

12
00:00:24.960 --> 00:00:26.680
Thank you, Cherokee, how are you?

13
00:00:26.680 --> 00:00:27.820
>> I'm doing wonderful, Jo.

14
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:31.570
We're just starting this new series, so
that's always an exciting time for me.

15
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:35.143
And then really, I've gotta ask you
the question I ask you all the time, Jo.

16
00:00:35.143 --> 00:00:36.177
Where are we starting?

17
00:00:36.177 --> 00:00:38.700
What will we be looking at
in this particular show?

18
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:41.304
>> I thought you were going
to ask me why am I here.

19
00:00:41.304 --> 00:00:43.538
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's the question she normally

20
00:00:43.538 --> 00:00:44.055
asks me.

21
00:00:44.055 --> 00:00:45.543
>> What are you doing here again?

22
00:00:45.543 --> 00:00:47.102
>> What are you doing here?

23
00:00:47.102 --> 00:00:51.780
[LAUGH] Right, well, as you've already
said, this is a brand new series.

24
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:56.230
And in this particular series,
we'll actually be looking at Agile testing

25
00:00:56.230 --> 00:01:00.240
methods and the types of testing
that we do within an Agile project.

26
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:04.910
So for this particular episode,
we're going to be doing a recap over

27
00:01:04.910 --> 00:01:10.180
Agile itself, what Agile is, and we'll
look at the principles of Agile as well.

28
00:01:10.180 --> 00:01:15.540
So this is our first episode, really out
first toe in the water in Agile testing.

29
00:01:15.540 --> 00:01:19.809
And certainly this particular episode
is really for those that have not yet

30
00:01:19.809 --> 00:01:22.320
seen our Agile fundamental series.

31
00:01:22.320 --> 00:01:25.080
And it's just a quick
recap over that series.

32
00:01:25.080 --> 00:01:27.440
>> Okay, great.
So even though I was part of that series,

33
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:29.810
this will be also great for
me just to get a refresher.

34
00:01:29.810 --> 00:01:31.340
Anyone else that may have watched it and

35
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:33.790
then needs to just kinda
have a recap as well.

36
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:37.200
>> What she's saying is she's forgotten.

37
00:01:37.200 --> 00:01:38.230
That's what she's saying.

38
00:01:38.230 --> 00:01:39.920
>> We'll see.

39
00:01:39.920 --> 00:01:41.530
>> But that's okay.

40
00:01:41.530 --> 00:01:45.390
Sometimes you don't actually get to watch
one series straight after another and

41
00:01:45.390 --> 00:01:46.080
that's all right.

42
00:01:46.080 --> 00:01:49.650
That's exactly why we do these
sort of quick recap introduction,

43
00:01:49.650 --> 00:01:53.520
cuz otherwise, how would you know
what it was we were talking about

44
00:01:53.520 --> 00:01:55.420
a little bit later on in another episode?

45
00:01:55.420 --> 00:01:57.740
So that's exactly why we do this.

46
00:01:57.740 --> 00:02:02.032
So let's start off with looking at
Agile itself and what is Agile.

47
00:02:02.032 --> 00:02:06.030
Well, you've already heard about Agile or
you wouldn't be here if you didn't know

48
00:02:06.030 --> 00:02:09.130
anything about Agile or
you hadn't heard about it.

49
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:13.760
Agile is a way of looking and
delivering projects and

50
00:02:13.760 --> 00:02:17.340
delivering software in
an incremental fashion.

51
00:02:17.340 --> 00:02:22.090
It's actually what we call continuous
delivery, and Agile allows us to

52
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:27.270
manage a project and to deliver the
benefits of a project to the organization

53
00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:32.090
in a way that is delivered on
an incremental or continual basis.

54
00:02:32.090 --> 00:02:34.690
And that's why we call
it continuous delivery.

55
00:02:34.690 --> 00:02:38.380
With an Agile project management
methodology, your customers,

56
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:41.990
your users are seeing
benefits almost immediately

57
00:02:41.990 --> 00:02:46.360
on a regular basis on an ongoing or
continual basis.

58
00:02:46.360 --> 00:02:49.150
So what we do with the Agile project is,

59
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:55.000
the Agile project is split into
what we call stories, user stories.

60
00:02:55.000 --> 00:02:58.280
And those stories,
we may choose to deliver just one or

61
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:02.990
we may choose to deliver three or
four at any one point in time, but

62
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:06.490
we group them into what
we call an iteration.

63
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:10.490
Sometimes, if you're using the Scrum
methodology, then we call that a sprint,

64
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.310
and every iteration lasts between one and
four weeks.

65
00:03:16.140 --> 00:03:19.790
So with each iteration, there you go,
you can see it in front of you.

66
00:03:19.790 --> 00:03:22.960
There you go, a very,
very simple iteration or sprint.

67
00:03:22.960 --> 00:03:24.830
Couldn't be simpler, right?

68
00:03:24.830 --> 00:03:27.342
Just looks like a big loopy arrow.

69
00:03:27.342 --> 00:03:28.569
[LAUGH]
>> We're gonna build on that.

70
00:03:28.569 --> 00:03:30.800
>> And that's the technical term.

71
00:03:30.800 --> 00:03:31.360
Just kidding.

72
00:03:31.360 --> 00:03:34.980
>> A big loopy arrow, right,
that lasts for four weeks.

73
00:03:34.980 --> 00:03:41.010
So with every single iteration then, we
start off with well, the project itself.

74
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:42.650
So we initiate the project.

75
00:03:42.650 --> 00:03:44.230
But what is included here?

76
00:03:44.230 --> 00:03:47.310
Right at the very beginning of
the project is the vision, and

77
00:03:47.310 --> 00:03:51.380
the goals of the project,
also the constraints of the project.

78
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:56.070
So things like, well, budgets,
that's a constraint, yeah.

79
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:57.480
The actual deliverable itself,

80
00:03:57.480 --> 00:04:00.740
believe it or not,
that could be a constraint as well.

81
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:04.610
Any sort of regulations that we may have,
what we might call the utility,

82
00:04:04.610 --> 00:04:06.750
in other words, what it's expected to do.

83
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:09.090
And also our warranty levels as well,

84
00:04:09.090 --> 00:04:13.970
in other words how we expect to work
with that particular end product.

85
00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:17.740
And then we have what we call our cost
grading requirements and estimates.

86
00:04:17.740 --> 00:04:23.580
When we say cost grading what we mean is,
we mean high level.

87
00:04:23.580 --> 00:04:26.940
We don't know really until we get
into the depths of our project,

88
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:30.240
we don't know exactly how long
everything is going to take.

89
00:04:30.240 --> 00:04:33.830
We don't know exactly how long each
particular piece of development work is

90
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:35.160
going to take.

91
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.920
It's what we would say in England is how
long is a piece of string measurement?

92
00:04:38.920 --> 00:04:39.720
And it really is.

93
00:04:39.720 --> 00:04:41.550
I mean, you ask me how long
is a piece of string and

94
00:04:41.550 --> 00:04:42.990
I'm going to shrug my shoulders.

95
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:45.660
And that's exactly where we
are at this point in time.

96
00:04:45.660 --> 00:04:50.104
So we take what we might
call here a ballpark figure,

97
00:04:50.104 --> 00:04:55.240
just an estimate, which is-
>> I know, I'm trying to rationalize this.

98
00:04:55.240 --> 00:04:57.790
I'm like,
coarse grained versus fine grained.

99
00:04:57.790 --> 00:05:00.648
I'm going the sandpaper method,
but okay, yeah.

100
00:05:00.648 --> 00:05:04.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, is that where it comes from?

101
00:05:04.070 --> 00:05:09.080
>> Yes, yeah, of course, kind of just
takes of the sort of the rough bits.

102
00:05:09.080 --> 00:05:12.209
Yeah, we're smoothing out the rough
bits right now, that's all we got to.

103
00:05:12.209 --> 00:05:17.396
[LAUGH] And then what we're going to be
doing as part of this planning is we're

104
00:05:17.396 --> 00:05:22.421
going to be, and take a look at our
Agile fundamentals class and we'll see

105
00:05:22.421 --> 00:05:27.550
how we actually look at the iteration or
the sprint, and planning as well.

106
00:05:27.550 --> 00:05:31.120
And what we've decided to
include in each iteration.

107
00:05:31.120 --> 00:05:35.290
So there we go,
we start off by initiating the project.

108
00:05:35.290 --> 00:05:38.911
And then, each iteration,
no matter what it's made up of,

109
00:05:38.911 --> 00:05:42.249
how many user stories,
we have to plan each iteration.

110
00:05:42.249 --> 00:05:46.210
But that's only gonna take between one and
four weeks.

111
00:05:46.210 --> 00:05:49.823
This is not going to take three months or
three years.

112
00:05:49.823 --> 00:05:51.984
This is not a waterfall project.

113
00:05:51.984 --> 00:05:57.259
This is literally going to be whatever
is possible, feasible, viable,

114
00:05:57.259 --> 00:06:03.229
whatever word you wanna use, whatever is
possible within those wonderful weeks.

115
00:06:03.229 --> 00:06:07.658
It's really perfectly feasible and viable,
and whatever else you wanna use as

116
00:06:07.658 --> 00:06:11.770
the word, to deliver an iteration
within two weeks or even within a week.

117
00:06:12.790 --> 00:06:17.540
So don't think that this can't be a real
project because I'm expected to deliver

118
00:06:17.540 --> 00:06:19.350
something every single week.

119
00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:24.280
This is definitely a real project, but
we're delivering in a continual way.

120
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:26.240
That's why we call it continuous delivery.

121
00:06:27.380 --> 00:06:30.970
During that particular iteration, and

122
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:35.130
we do this for every single iteration,
we have something that's very close to my

123
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:38.560
heart because this is something
that we do here every single day.

124
00:06:38.560 --> 00:06:41.580
Is that we have our
daily stand-up meeting.

125
00:06:41.580 --> 00:06:43.760
So and
now I'm gonna put Cherokee on the spot.

126
00:06:43.760 --> 00:06:45.210
>> Sure, yeah, right!

127
00:06:45.210 --> 00:06:46.279
>> Just because-

128
00:06:46.279 --> 00:06:47.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> I like to really.

129
00:06:47.215 --> 00:06:49.515
>> Why not?
>> Why not?

130
00:06:49.515 --> 00:06:51.730
Now we've already looked
at stand-up meetings.

131
00:06:51.730 --> 00:06:56.000
We did this in another series,
in our Agile fundamentals.

132
00:06:56.000 --> 00:06:59.370
Can you remember then why
we did a stand-up meeting?

133
00:06:59.370 --> 00:07:04.351
Okay, so we want to go ahead and
let everyone know

134
00:07:04.351 --> 00:07:08.735
about any accomplishments, obstacles.

135
00:07:08.735 --> 00:07:09.347
I'm trying to think.

136
00:07:09.347 --> 00:07:16.200
Accomplishments, obstacles, and
maybe shout outs or recognition.

137
00:07:17.920 --> 00:07:19.440
Okay, I'm impressed by that.

138
00:07:19.440 --> 00:07:19.940
>> Okay.
>> Yeah.

139
00:07:19.940 --> 00:07:22.277
>> Yeah, I don't know the exact technical

140
00:07:22.277 --> 00:07:24.830
terms we might have used, but yeah.

141
00:07:24.830 --> 00:07:27.200
>> Well, think of every standup
meeting as a planning meeting.

142
00:07:27.200 --> 00:07:31.780
So think about what we do here and what
we do is we really go around the room and

143
00:07:31.780 --> 00:07:34.990
we say right, this is what's
on our agenda for today, yes.

144
00:07:34.990 --> 00:07:39.560
So we will tell everybody in a standup
meeting what each developer is doing for

145
00:07:39.560 --> 00:07:41.010
that particular day.

146
00:07:41.010 --> 00:07:42.878
So in our case we will stand up and

147
00:07:42.878 --> 00:07:45.727
we will say this is what
content I'm producing.

148
00:07:45.727 --> 00:07:50.706
But it's also an opportunity for those in
the standup to, as you have already said,

149
00:07:50.706 --> 00:07:54.830
highlight any accomplishments
what we've already achieved.

150
00:07:54.830 --> 00:07:58.931
Also to highlight any
obstacles that we might face.

151
00:07:58.931 --> 00:08:02.051
Because this is your opportunity and
that's standup meeting for

152
00:08:02.051 --> 00:08:05.110
somebody to turn around and
say hey, look, I can help.

153
00:08:05.110 --> 00:08:05.910
>> Right.

154
00:08:05.910 --> 00:08:09.700
>> And again, in standup meeting we
want to reward and recognize too, so

155
00:08:09.700 --> 00:08:13.690
we do want to,
I was gonna say call out anybody but

156
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:16.370
give them the recognition
that they deserve.

157
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:19.940
No, this is not a place where we
point fingers and apportion blame.

158
00:08:19.940 --> 00:08:23.330
>> No, and I'm just thinking shout out,
like, I don't know.

159
00:08:23.330 --> 00:08:27.790
Did you ever call up the radio line,
I wanna give a shoutout to Emily, my bff?

160
00:08:27.790 --> 00:08:28.590
No?

161
00:08:28.590 --> 00:08:29.135
>> No.
>> No?

162
00:08:29.135 --> 00:08:32.990
[LAUGH]
>> I'm not saying a word.

163
00:08:32.990 --> 00:08:35.330
>> That was like
>> So-

164
00:08:35.330 --> 00:08:38.431
>> Leave that one there [LAUGH]

165
00:08:38.431 --> 00:08:39.514
>> [LAUGH]

166
00:08:39.514 --> 00:08:40.240
>> Anyhow.

167
00:08:40.240 --> 00:08:42.650
>> No. No. I think we were
a little bit more reserved.

168
00:08:42.650 --> 00:08:44.400
I think we would say, hi.

169
00:08:44.400 --> 00:08:47.510
>> Okay.
>> I just wanna say hi to the person that

170
00:08:47.510 --> 00:08:48.910
I really, really, really like.

171
00:08:48.910 --> 00:08:51.070
But I don't want to tell
them that's it's me.

172
00:08:51.070 --> 00:08:53.900
Could you please make sure
that you disguise my voice.

173
00:08:53.900 --> 00:08:56.130
That sort of thing-
>> Okay.

174
00:08:56.130 --> 00:08:57.375
>> That sounded creepy, right?

175
00:08:57.375 --> 00:08:59.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, okay, let's move on very,

176
00:08:59.520 --> 00:09:00.500
very quickly then.

177
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:02.940
[LAUGH] So
during that development period then,

178
00:09:02.940 --> 00:09:06.240
we're gonna have thee daily standup
meetings and those daily standup meetings,

179
00:09:06.240 --> 00:09:09.230
you'll see what comes out of those
meetings is the project status.

180
00:09:09.230 --> 00:09:14.500
We're gonna talk about and look at exactly

181
00:09:14.500 --> 00:09:19.820
how we can visualize and how we can
demonstrate what our progress is,

182
00:09:19.820 --> 00:09:23.200
bearing in mind, agile doesn't
mean no documentation at all.

183
00:09:23.200 --> 00:09:24.830
And that's what people think.

184
00:09:24.830 --> 00:09:28.028
People tend to think with agile
there's no documentation cuz we're

185
00:09:28.028 --> 00:09:33.380
focused on efficiencies but
you've gotta have some visible

186
00:09:33.380 --> 00:09:37.300
method to represent the progress
of the project, you have to.

187
00:09:37.300 --> 00:09:40.190
>> Just eliminating the wasteful
documentation, right Jo?

188
00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:41.540
>> Right, exactly.

189
00:09:41.540 --> 00:09:44.010
You have to have the documentation.

190
00:09:44.010 --> 00:09:48.690
And even if it is, the fact that and I've
seen a lot of organizations that do this.

191
00:09:48.690 --> 00:09:49.860
We've got our Kanban board,

192
00:09:49.860 --> 00:09:52.750
which is our board that tells us
what we've still got to do for

193
00:09:52.750 --> 00:09:56.390
that particular iteration, what's in
progress and what's been completed.

194
00:09:56.390 --> 00:09:59.910
And I have seen organizations that
will use these smart boards now.

195
00:09:59.910 --> 00:10:04.479
Or even where they'll simply take a photo
of the board on a daily basis, so

196
00:10:04.479 --> 00:10:08.314
maybe twice today and
that's uploaded into the share drive so

197
00:10:08.314 --> 00:10:12.825
that everybody can see exactly what
the progress is, if any user story.

198
00:10:12.825 --> 00:10:16.955
And so there has to be some form of
documentation, keep it informal,

199
00:10:16.955 --> 00:10:21.440
keep it at a high level, it's got to
be there and it's got to be efficient,

200
00:10:21.440 --> 00:10:23.410

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.

gonna do is we're gonna part up that user

425
00:22:33.596 --> 00:22:36.906
story and we're gonna add it to
the backbone for the next iteration, and

426
00:22:36.906 --> 00:22:39.748
it may well be that, yeah,
we have to find another supplier.

427
00:22:39.748 --> 00:22:43.420
And the same can be said,
for when testing fails.

428
00:22:44.850 --> 00:22:48.459
So we're doing all of these testing
in all of four quadrants and

429
00:22:48.459 --> 00:22:49.830
something goes wrong.

430
00:22:49.830 --> 00:22:53.890
Something fails this test, again,
you're doing exactly the same thing,

431
00:22:53.890 --> 00:23:00.710
you're going to add it to your backlog,
you're not going to delay the iteration.

432
00:23:00.710 --> 00:23:02.950
That's one thing that
we should never do in

433
00:23:04.320 --> 00:23:07.140
an Agile environment is
to delay the iteration.

434
00:23:07.140 --> 00:23:10.276
We should always select,
this is my cut off point and

435
00:23:10.276 --> 00:23:13.650
we don't like bureaucracy and
we don't like contact.

436
00:23:13.650 --> 00:23:16.960
But we do want to be able to commit

437
00:23:16.960 --> 00:23:21.200
to delivering certain products at
certain time so the iteration.

438
00:23:21.200 --> 00:23:22.260
And then therefore,

439
00:23:22.260 --> 00:23:27.300
the subsequent release we want to
deliver to a specific point in time.

440
00:23:27.300 --> 00:23:31.487
So we don't delay that,
if something doesn't work,

441
00:23:31.487 --> 00:23:34.134
then it gets added to the backlog.

442
00:23:34.134 --> 00:23:38.332
If we're not getting the right
response from a supplier,

443
00:23:38.332 --> 00:23:43.120
then again, that story get shelved and
added to the backlog.

444
00:23:43.120 --> 00:23:49.100
We don't just wait, that's the one
thing that we don't do within Agile

445
00:23:49.100 --> 00:23:52.330
from a project management perspective,
it just doesn't make any sense at all.

446
00:23:53.920 --> 00:23:58.950
So we've looked very briefly
at testing quadrants.

447
00:23:58.950 --> 00:24:02.328
And in our next episode, what we're
actually going to be looking at is

448
00:24:02.328 --> 00:24:06.571
collaboration, and collaboration across
our development teams, and we're gonna be

449
00:24:06.571 --> 00:24:10.550
delve in further into the collaboration
with our suppliers and with our vendors.

450
00:24:10.550 --> 00:24:14.190
But for now that's it for
this particular episode.

451
00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:16.980
And we'll see you in the next episode.
>> Thank you so much, Jo for

452
00:24:16.980 --> 00:24:21.090
not making me do math and for
explaining this Agile Quadrants.

453
00:24:21.090 --> 00:24:24.250
And thank you for joining us, but
we are gonna go ahead and sign out.

454
00:24:24.250 --> 00:24:26.206
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

455
00:24:26.206 --> 00:24:28.250
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

456
00:24:28.250 --> 00:24:31.195
[MUSIC]

457
00:24:31.195 --> 00:24:36.525
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.
episodes.title: Development for Testing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:06.360
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.360 --> 00:00:07.877
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.877 --> 00:00:11.852
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.852 --> 00:00:14.780
>> Welcome everyone to
your Agile testing series.

5
00:00:14.780 --> 00:00:16.780
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:16.780 --> 00:00:20.690
In this episode we'll be taking a look at
development for testing and with us today,

7
00:00:20.690 --> 00:00:23.470
back in studios, we have Mrs. Jo Peacock.

8
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:24.530
How's it going today Jo?

9
00:00:24.530 --> 00:00:25.850
>> Absolutely great, thank you Cherokee.

10
00:00:25.850 --> 00:00:26.460
How are you?

11
00:00:26.460 --> 00:00:27.520
I'm doing wonderful,

12
00:00:27.520 --> 00:00:30.830
we said we were gonna get our toes
wet in the last couple episodes.

13
00:00:30.830 --> 00:00:34.220
So are we like, slowly walking
into that really cold water,

14
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:35.385
is that what's happening right now?

15
00:00:35.385 --> 00:00:38.225
>> [LAUGH] I think yesterday, we dived
right in well and truly, didn't we?

16
00:00:38.225 --> 00:00:41.854
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you remember we looked at those

17
00:00:41.854 --> 00:00:45.600
testing quadrants in
that previous episode.

18
00:00:45.600 --> 00:00:47.850
And we looked at the various
types of tests that we do.

19
00:00:47.850 --> 00:00:50.620
>> Yes.
>> Well, now we look at how we in this

20
00:00:50.620 --> 00:00:54.310
particular episode, we're gonna
look at how we develop to test.

21
00:00:54.310 --> 00:00:57.450
It's kind of a bit of
a tongue twister right?

22
00:00:57.450 --> 00:00:59.020
Development for testing.

23
00:00:59.020 --> 00:01:03.430
But the idea is that when you
developing your software,

24
00:01:03.430 --> 00:01:04.940
you know what you're going to test.

25
00:01:04.940 --> 00:01:08.590
And so you develop it to be tested.

26
00:01:08.590 --> 00:01:10.730
Kind of make sense, right?

27
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:11.460
>> Yeah.

28
00:01:11.460 --> 00:01:14.500
Like with anything, if you know
a car has to drive on the road,

29
00:01:14.500 --> 00:01:16.060
you're gonna put the wheels on it.

30
00:01:16.060 --> 00:01:19.330
Cars have wheels, you are gonna
make sure that the wheels turn.

31
00:01:19.330 --> 00:01:21.850
>> I like that actually, yes,
that's exactly what it is.

32
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:25.120
You know what the purpose of that
particular piece of software is,

33
00:01:25.120 --> 00:01:27.800
or that car is,
you know it's got to get you from A to B.

34
00:01:27.800 --> 00:01:31.200
So you're going to test
the thing's ability to drive.

35
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:33.654
>> [LAUGH]
>> And your ability to steer it as well.

36
00:01:33.654 --> 00:01:36.201
So this is what we're going to be doing.

37
00:01:36.201 --> 00:01:40.665
We're just going to be looking at
the types of tests that we have for

38
00:01:40.665 --> 00:01:45.065
all of our software and also how
we then develop to do the testing.

39
00:01:45.065 --> 00:01:49.711
So you don't develop something, and
this is a common misconception and

40
00:01:49.711 --> 00:01:53.214
it happens in IT a lot,
is that we develop something and

41
00:01:53.214 --> 00:01:56.830
then we think about
the testing afterwards.

42
00:01:56.830 --> 00:02:00.220
And then that's when we say, right,
okay, what is it we want to test and

43
00:02:00.220 --> 00:02:02.010
we might test for usability.

44
00:02:02.010 --> 00:02:05.380
But then we don't really know
how the user's going to use it.

45
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:08.870
Because if we haven't have that
collaboration with the user or we maybe

46
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:14.060
don't understand our users, then we don't
know really know exactly what to test for.

47
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:19.530
And so what we say now is remember
everything I have always said about agile,

48
00:02:19.530 --> 00:02:22.890
it's about common sense written down and
this exactly what it is.

49
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:28.120
It's just like you know you gonna test, so
let's develop it so that it can be tested.

50
00:02:28.120 --> 00:02:32.350
And let's develop it so that it does
meet the need to the organization.

51
00:02:32.350 --> 00:02:39.170
>> Right, I've seen things where
companies have just had bolt ons or

52
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:43.940
afterthoughts just kind
of bandaged on there, and

53
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:46.770
it never really works out that well.

54
00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:50.960
So just thinking about it from the onset,
the planning, and

55
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:54.740
getting it into our sprint or
our iteration.

56
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:56.358
And just thinking about it ahead of time.

57
00:02:56.358 --> 00:02:59.330
>> Yeah, that's exactly what we're doing.

58
00:02:59.330 --> 00:03:02.910
We're acknowledging really
that we're going to test.

59
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:09.100
And I wonder how many pieces of software
we've developed to not even tested.

60
00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:11.700
I wonder how many pieces of software,

61
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:15.540
how many solutions are just
deployed without the testing.

62
00:03:15.540 --> 00:03:17.555
Or maybe, I don't know about you but

63
00:03:17.555 --> 00:03:21.005
I've heard all of this,
we test it in the live environment.

64
00:03:21.005 --> 00:03:22.640
No, you don't right.

65
00:03:22.640 --> 00:03:26.584
You test it before it goes live,
there's such a thing as beta testing or

66
00:03:26.584 --> 00:03:28.115
how would you say that now?

67
00:03:28.115 --> 00:03:30.042
>> Beta.
>> Right beta.

68
00:03:30.042 --> 00:03:31.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> Testing [LAUGH] right.

69
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:33.680
There's such a thing as beta testing and

70
00:03:33.680 --> 00:03:37.500
so that's testing it in
the live environment.

71
00:03:37.500 --> 00:03:39.960
And you've got testing environments too.

72
00:03:39.960 --> 00:03:44.800
So we got to make sure though that when
we do the development we consider that

73
00:03:44.800 --> 00:03:47.580
they're all going to be tests for it.

74
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:51.458
So what I wanna do in the first
couple of slides is I really wanna

75
00:03:51.458 --> 00:03:56.393
look at just the difference between sort
of the developer and the tester role.

76
00:03:56.393 --> 00:04:00.156
One rule, one rule, just one rule that
I'm going to give on this one, and

77
00:04:00.156 --> 00:04:03.950
that is that the person that develops
shouldn't be the person to test it.

78
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:04.530
>> I agree.

79
00:04:05.550 --> 00:04:10.588
>> It's simple, cuz if I develop
something, and because I may,

80
00:04:10.588 --> 00:04:15.636
[LAUGH] if I develop something and
I test it then I know what to do.

81
00:04:15.636 --> 00:04:17.997
And I know not only how
to make it look good, and

82
00:04:17.997 --> 00:04:21.691
it's not that I'm being vain about it but
know how to make it look good but

83
00:04:21.691 --> 00:04:24.540
I know also how to fix it
if something goes wrong.

84
00:04:24.540 --> 00:04:29.100
And so there are gonna be a lot of
things to get lost in that development.

85
00:04:29.100 --> 00:04:30.650
Because, well,

86
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:34.550
we don't necessarily accurately
report the results of our testing.

87
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:38.345
Cuz you tend to sort of like
you know just dip into things.

88
00:04:38.345 --> 00:04:40.545
No one try this out,
no one try that out, and-

89
00:04:40.545 --> 00:04:42.005
>> Well if you developed it and

90
00:04:42.005 --> 00:04:44.975
it make sense to you, then that's perfect.

91
00:04:44.975 --> 00:04:46.345
But that's not the end user.

92
00:04:46.345 --> 00:04:50.075
So what if I can get some kind of sample
groups to go ahead and test this or

93
00:04:50.075 --> 00:04:54.185
maybe appear to go ahead and run through
it to see if there are things that

94
00:04:54.185 --> 00:04:57.120
I didn't think about that you
might have thought about.

95
00:04:57.120 --> 00:05:02.140
But, you just said that if I developed it,
it makes sense to me.

96
00:05:02.140 --> 00:05:05.270
And this is exactly the same
way as we're working right now.

97
00:05:05.270 --> 00:05:07.760
What I'm saying makes
perfect sense to me [LAUGH].

98
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:11.310
You might not be able to understand
what I'm saying, and you are here-

99
00:05:11.310 --> 00:05:12.530
>> That's my biggest challenge.

100
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:15.700
Like I have Cherokee speak and
I think Jo is like starting to learn it.

101
00:05:15.700 --> 00:05:17.070
Hopefully you are too.

102
00:05:17.070 --> 00:05:18.290
But it's a little crazy.

103
00:05:18.290 --> 00:05:20.770
>> But you're here for
my sanity check, right?

104
00:05:20.770 --> 00:05:21.520
You are here.

105
00:05:21.520 --> 00:05:24.480
You're the one that says, yeah,
I don't know what you're going on about.

106
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:26.155
I really don't know what you're saying.

107
00:05:26.155 --> 00:05:28.190
>> Right, and Adam says this a lot.

108
00:05:28.190 --> 00:05:31.170
He's like, all right Cherokee, you gotta
keep me honest here because if I'm saying

109
00:05:31.170 --> 00:05:34.550
something that doesn't make sense or
whatever, just make sure that they know.

110
00:05:34.550 --> 00:05:36.740
>> Right, and that's exactly it.

111
00:05:36.740 --> 00:05:41.100
You are here to be the person that would
normally be asking me the questions.

112
00:05:41.100 --> 00:05:45.780
That's why you're here and
I can say exactly what I want to say, but

113
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:48.420
at the end of the day,
if it only makes sense to me, it's no use.

114
00:05:48.420 --> 00:05:50.240
And it's the same with development.

115
00:05:50.240 --> 00:05:52.330
If it only makes sense to the developer or

116
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:56.070
if it only works from the developer's
perspective, then that's not gonna be any

117
00:05:56.070 --> 00:05:59.860
value once we get it deployed and
once it's in the live environment.

118
00:05:59.860 --> 00:06:05.050
So its really important,
and this is why I've titled

119
00:06:05.050 --> 00:06:08.990
this slide collaborating with developers,
it's really important that the test

120
00:06:08.990 --> 00:06:13.780
collaborates with the developer, but it's
also important that tester is impartial.

121
00:06:13.780 --> 00:06:17.810
It's important that the tester
is somebody that understands

122
00:06:17.810 --> 00:06:20.260
the product from a high level.

123
00:06:20.260 --> 00:06:24.750
But it's also important
that the tester is not

124
00:06:24.750 --> 00:06:27.500
the person that's doing
the development work.

125
00:06:27.500 --> 00:06:30.190
It's not somebody with
a biased perspective on it.

126
00:06:30.190 --> 00:06:33.730
Or someone who really understands cuz
they've helped with the development.

127
00:06:33.730 --> 00:06:37.970
So if you look at the difference
there between the developer role and

128
00:06:37.970 --> 00:06:41.250
tester role you'll see
some fairly obvious ones.

129
00:06:41.250 --> 00:06:44.790
The developer works out the story details,

130
00:06:44.790 --> 00:06:48.440
whereas the tester is going to
participate in that discussion.

131
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:52.140
But you see, let's think about
this from a practical perspective.

132
00:06:52.140 --> 00:06:56.430
So I'm a developer and
you're my tester, and

133
00:06:56.430 --> 00:07:00.150
I'm a developer and
let's pretend we've got the user or

134
00:07:00.150 --> 00:07:03.870
maybe a product owner in the room,
and they've given us a story.

135
00:07:05.510 --> 00:07:07.090
What am I interested in?

136
00:07:07.090 --> 00:07:12.080
Well, I'm interested in, okay, how am I
going to be able to deliver that story?

137
00:07:12.080 --> 00:07:14.810
I'm interested in how am I going

138
00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:18.670
to develop this in a way that
they're gonna be able to use it.

139
00:07:18.670 --> 00:07:23.700
But yet, you, what you're thinking about
is well, how am I going to test this?

140
00:07:23.700 --> 00:07:25.740
How am I gonna check that it works?

141
00:07:25.740 --> 00:07:28.090
So you're thinking about the usability.

142
00:07:28.090 --> 00:07:32.581
You're writing down and
participating by asking questions.

143
00:07:32.581 --> 00:07:37.510
You're writing down exactly
what you're gonna need to test.

144
00:07:37.510 --> 00:07:38.830
>> Like, what does that mean, Jo?

145
00:07:38.830 --> 00:07:41.369
What are you talking about Jo?

146
00:07:41.369 --> 00:07:43.384
>> Right.
>> [LAUGH]

147
00:07:44.680 --> 00:07:47.420
>> So, whereas, remember I talked about in

148
00:07:47.420 --> 00:07:50.370
one of our previous episodes
about customer experience and

149
00:07:50.370 --> 00:07:52.440
about sort of moments of truth.

150
00:07:52.440 --> 00:07:54.565
As a tester you're concerned with that.

151
00:07:54.565 --> 00:07:58.746
And if you thought about the quadrants
that we looked at in previous episodes

152
00:07:58.746 --> 00:08:03.075
as well, There's a test that you're
thinking about all of those quadrants.

153
00:08:03.075 --> 00:08:07.105
You're thinking about testing not just
does it just work without any errors,

154
00:08:07.105 --> 00:08:10.090
but does it do what it's supposed to do?

155
00:08:10.090 --> 00:08:12.330
And how easy is it to use?

156
00:08:12.330 --> 00:08:13.990
That's the usability test.

157
00:08:13.990 --> 00:08:18.510
And also then there's the security
aspect and the sort of the availability

158
00:08:18.510 --> 00:08:21.870
aspect and actually,
is it there when I want it to be there?

159
00:08:21.870 --> 00:08:24.330
>> Right, and who are we interfacing with?

160
00:08:24.330 --> 00:08:28.500
>> Right, so that's you're looking at that
and as a developer, I'm not gonna turn

161
00:08:28.500 --> 00:08:32.790
around and say, I don't care about that,
cuz that would be wrong, right?

162
00:08:32.790 --> 00:08:37.630
But as a developer, that's not
top of my priority list to test.

163
00:08:38.870 --> 00:08:44.829
I'm interested in designing for that and
I'm interested in developing for security.

164
00:08:44.829 --> 00:08:49.650
But I'm not gonna know just how
secure it is until you've tested it.

165
00:08:50.990 --> 00:08:52.210
I am not going to be the one,

166
00:08:52.210 --> 00:08:55.098
if I'm designing something
that sits behind a firewall.

167
00:08:55.098 --> 00:08:58.500
I'm not gonna be the one that's
going to fire a virus at it to check

168
00:09:00.360 --> 00:09:02.580
that it's not gonna fail, that's your job.

169
00:09:03.890 --> 00:09:06.698
And your job is possibly to go out
there and find a good virus maybe-

170
00:09:06.698 --> 00:09:07.410
>> Try to break it.

171
00:09:07.410 --> 00:09:09.552
>> Right, that's exactly what your job is.

172
00:09:09.552 --> 00:09:13.850
And we used to use terms
like sort of stress testing.

173
00:09:13.850 --> 00:09:15.410
We should still use those terms.

174
00:09:15.410 --> 00:09:17.380
That's what you're gonna do,
you're gonna test it till it breaks.

175
00:09:19.430 --> 00:09:23.580
So on the slide that you've got in front
of you there is really just a guide, and

176
00:09:23.580 --> 00:09:26.065
it's just something that,
because we can't be too specific.

177
00:09:26.065 --> 00:09:30.180
Cuz we don't know what is that
you are personally developing and

178
00:09:30.180 --> 00:09:33.090
what your project is going to achieve.

179
00:09:33.090 --> 00:09:37.810
But that is just a guide for
the difference between development and

180
00:09:37.810 --> 00:09:39.780
testing is something
that you can refer to,

181
00:09:39.780 --> 00:09:44.280
you can download this material and it's
something that you can refer to later on.

182
00:09:44.280 --> 00:09:47.490
Now, I have spoken in
previous episodes and

183
00:09:47.490 --> 00:09:53.370
we'd looked at our Agile fundamentals
series and we talked about pairing.

184
00:09:53.370 --> 00:09:55.130
>> Right, working together.

185
00:09:55.130 --> 00:09:58.060
>> Working together,
working in collaboration.

186
00:09:58.060 --> 00:10:00.810
But ultimately it's still the same rule.

187
00:10:00.810 --> 00:10:02.340
Even if we're working together,

188
00:10:02.340 --> 00:10:05.870
I'll be developing one aspect,
you'll test that aspect.

189
00:10:05.870 --> 00:10:08.770
You will develop another aspect and
I'll test that aspect.

190
00:10:10.990 --> 00:10:15.120
Understand that in any team
we've got all different skills.

191
00:10:16.200 --> 00:10:18.910
Your skills are far more

really wasn't focused on.

420
00:24:16.950 --> 00:24:19.490
But now it's kind of an emphasis.

421
00:24:19.490 --> 00:24:21.940
So I wanna make sure
that that's also working.

422
00:24:21.940 --> 00:24:23.460
Is that what you're talking about here?

423
00:24:23.460 --> 00:24:25.610
>> No, that might be an additional story.

424
00:24:25.610 --> 00:24:28.521
Because that sounds to me like
additional functionality.

425
00:24:28.521 --> 00:24:29.735
>> Okay.
>> Right, okay.

426
00:24:29.735 --> 00:24:32.540
And that's one thing that we
don't do in an Agile project.

427
00:24:32.540 --> 00:24:34.194
>> Right.
>> In an Agile project,

428
00:24:34.194 --> 00:24:36.531
we don' move the goalposts as I would say.

429
00:24:36.531 --> 00:24:41.276
Okay, my user story is my user story and
if there's additional functionality,

430
00:24:41.276 --> 00:24:44.626
then although we accommodate change and
we love change,

431
00:24:44.626 --> 00:24:48.390
any new functionality that comes
in is an additional story.

432
00:24:48.390 --> 00:24:49.140
>> Okay.

433
00:24:49.140 --> 00:24:52.968
>> What we doing here is, we're testing
that the original story that we

434
00:24:52.968 --> 00:24:56.533
started to develop,
we're testing that that actually works.

435
00:24:56.533 --> 00:25:01.000
And that it works in all of my, what I'm
doing here is I'm looking at my scenario.

436
00:25:01.000 --> 00:25:05.635
So what I'm saying is okay, I've
looked at in my acceptance test, well,

437
00:25:05.635 --> 00:25:09.970
what I'm doing is I'm testing
that it sends and receives email.

438
00:25:09.970 --> 00:25:13.013
And so the natural place
to test that it sends and

439
00:25:13.013 --> 00:25:16.679
receives email is here on my laptop,
so I'm doing that.

440
00:25:16.679 --> 00:25:21.585
But what I'm looking at here in my
behavior driven testing is, okay,

441
00:25:21.585 --> 00:25:26.505
but now, does it do it on my cell phone
and now does it do it on my tablet.

442
00:25:26.505 --> 00:25:30.395
>> Network and they're outside of our
organization and things like that.

443
00:25:30.395 --> 00:25:33.198
>> Right, so
I'm testing the same functionality-

444
00:25:33.198 --> 00:25:35.450
>> Same feature got it.

445
00:25:35.450 --> 00:25:36.126
>> But in different scenarios.

446
00:25:36.126 --> 00:25:39.812
So in this particular
scenario does it work or

447
00:25:39.812 --> 00:25:43.830
maybe if I keep my caps
lock on does this work.

448
00:25:43.830 --> 00:25:48.802
Maybe things like you get those passwords,
good lord.

449
00:25:48.802 --> 00:25:50.618
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean,

450
00:25:50.618 --> 00:25:53.310
those passwords that are case
sensitive drive me mad.

451
00:25:53.310 --> 00:25:57.678
I mean, and sometimes my PC reminds
me that I've got my caps lock on and

452
00:25:57.678 --> 00:25:59.320
other times it doesn't.

453
00:25:59.320 --> 00:26:04.112
And sometimes these websites will
tell you that your password,

454
00:26:04.112 --> 00:26:06.340
the field is case sensitive.

455
00:26:06.340 --> 00:26:08.160
And sometimes,
it doesn't even bother telling you.

456
00:26:08.160 --> 00:26:12.338
So you don't realize until you go to log
in to that particular website again.

457
00:26:12.338 --> 00:26:14.980
[LAUGH] That's frustrating.

458
00:26:14.980 --> 00:26:17.544
But that's again,
about mapping out the customer experience.

459
00:26:17.544 --> 00:26:24.850
And development that doesn't understand
the full customer experience.

460
00:26:24.850 --> 00:26:26.590
That's what the result is.

461
00:26:26.590 --> 00:26:27.745
That's what you get.

462
00:26:27.745 --> 00:26:30.520
Is something that's missed out.

463
00:26:30.520 --> 00:26:35.420
So something where again, going into
a password field where that password

464
00:26:35.420 --> 00:26:40.340
simply doesn't bother telling you whether
the case sensitivity is important or not.

465
00:26:40.340 --> 00:26:41.686
That's been overlooked and

466
00:26:41.686 --> 00:26:45.050
it's been overlooked because
it's been an assumption.

467
00:26:45.050 --> 00:26:48.187
And it's been an assumption on
the part of the development team or

468
00:26:48.187 --> 00:26:51.450
assumption on the part of the tester or
maybe an assumption on both.

469
00:26:51.450 --> 00:26:54.434
And that's another downside
to the developer and

470
00:26:54.434 --> 00:26:58.909
the tester actually working too closely
during the development process,

471
00:26:58.909 --> 00:27:01.480
is that you can both
assume the same thing.

472
00:27:03.310 --> 00:27:05.240
If I consult you while I'm developing.

473
00:27:05.240 --> 00:27:07.484
>> We may have similar patterns or

474
00:27:07.484 --> 00:27:13.240
work experience that kind of twine us
together and make those same mistakes.

475
00:27:13.240 --> 00:27:15.596
>> Right and it means that you
don't actually test fully.

476
00:27:16.810 --> 00:27:19.063
And it's not tested until
it gets to the customer.

477
00:27:19.063 --> 00:27:23.433
And then at that point in time that's when
we then have to bring in a new iteration

478
00:27:23.433 --> 00:27:27.087
to probably amend something that
wasn't quite developed right or

479
00:27:27.087 --> 00:27:30.174
maybe didn't quite worked
the way we expected it to do.

480
00:27:30.174 --> 00:27:35.390
Most mistakes are made during this time.

481
00:27:35.390 --> 00:27:39.780
Most mistakes in development
are actually made because testing

482
00:27:39.780 --> 00:27:42.590
wasn't sufficient enough.

483
00:27:42.590 --> 00:27:48.620
And generally,
that is because we wrote down the user

484
00:27:48.620 --> 00:27:53.370
story, we acknowledged and
we agreed on the user story,

485
00:27:53.370 --> 00:27:57.670
but we didn't quite understand
the customer experience.

486
00:27:57.670 --> 00:28:02.040
We didn't understand the moments
of truth and we didn't understand

487
00:28:02.040 --> 00:28:06.710
what it is we were actually trying
to develop and how the user worked.

488
00:28:06.710 --> 00:28:08.470
And in fact, while we've been talking,

489
00:28:08.470 --> 00:28:12.370
somebody has mentioned in our chatroom
about yes you've got to do that.

490
00:28:12.370 --> 00:28:20.190
It does take more time, but you have to
map out those exact user moments of truth.

491
00:28:20.190 --> 00:28:23.740
You have to map out
the exact user experience.

492
00:28:23.740 --> 00:28:25.920
You cannot rely on assumptions.

493
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:30.040
And the thing is with IT is
that we're terrible for it.

494
00:28:30.040 --> 00:28:31.390
We really do.

495
00:28:31.390 --> 00:28:34.420
Cherokee is the worst, as we clearly see.

496
00:28:34.420 --> 00:28:35.619
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is twice she's done this now.

497
00:28:35.619 --> 00:28:39.134
[LAUGH] But yeah,
we've gotta ensure that we understand

498
00:28:39.134 --> 00:28:44.250
exactly what our customer and our user
want and how they're going to work.

499
00:28:44.250 --> 00:28:48.440
And so we'll bring in people like business
relationship management type roles

500
00:28:48.440 --> 00:28:50.880
that can help us with that.

501
00:28:50.880 --> 00:28:56.300
So for this particular episode,
really the concentration has

502
00:28:56.300 --> 00:29:01.590
been on the different types of development
that we have to do in order to be able to

503
00:29:01.590 --> 00:29:06.710
test and as I've said,
we are developing for testing.

504
00:29:06.710 --> 00:29:11.680
So remember, we have our test driven
development where we're testing just

505
00:29:11.680 --> 00:29:15.500
the code and we're testing that it
doesn't have any particular errors.

506
00:29:15.500 --> 00:29:20.080
We have our acceptance test development,
where we are testing for

507
00:29:20.080 --> 00:29:23.960
the end result, does it actually
do what it's supposed to do.

508
00:29:23.960 --> 00:29:26.310
And then we've got our
behaviour driven development,

509
00:29:26.310 --> 00:29:30.020
where we're testing various scenarios,
we're testing out that usability section.

510
00:29:31.530 --> 00:29:32.295
>> All right Jo, so

511
00:29:32.295 --> 00:29:35.373
do we have anymore testing to
cover in this particular episode?

512
00:29:35.373 --> 00:29:38.428
>> Yes, we're going to test out
storytelling in our next episode, but

513
00:29:38.428 --> 00:29:39.400
not in this one no.

514
00:29:39.400 --> 00:29:42.280
>> Storytelling, like circle time,
pick out our favourite book.

515
00:29:42.280 --> 00:29:42.998
>> Yeah why not.

516
00:29:42.998 --> 00:29:45.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think I've got a few,

517
00:29:45.100 --> 00:29:49.750
I'm not too sure which one I want
to pick out as the, as my favorite.

518
00:29:49.750 --> 00:29:52.910
>> You know nowadays we have Alexa and
Alexa can read us books,

519
00:29:52.910 --> 00:29:54.390
we don't even have to read anymore.

520
00:29:54.390 --> 00:29:57.543
Can you imagine how smart we're getting,
like with our smartphones and

521
00:29:57.543 --> 00:29:59.620
now our assistants,
our virtual assistants.

522
00:29:59.620 --> 00:30:03.686
>> Yeah, but
my Alexa has got a British male voice.

523
00:30:03.686 --> 00:30:05.667
>> Ooh, Alex.

524
00:30:05.667 --> 00:30:08.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyhow, we'll sign out.

525
00:30:08.810 --> 00:30:10.360
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

526
00:30:10.360 --> 00:30:12.880
>> And I'm Jo Peacock
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

[MUSIC]

00:30:22.114 --> 00:30:25.008
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO TV.

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.
episodes.title: Testing for Story-Telling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.355 --> 00:00:01.376
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.376 --> 00:00:06.215
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.215 --> 00:00:08.410
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.410 --> 00:00:11.937
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.937 --> 00:00:14.424
>> Welcome everyone to
your Agile testing series.

6
00:00:14.424 --> 00:00:16.651
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.651 --> 00:00:18.672
In this episode, just as Jo promised,

8
00:00:18.672 --> 00:00:21.384
we're gonna be taking a look
at some storytelling.

9
00:00:21.384 --> 00:00:24.601
Actually, we're gonna be testing for
story telling and

10
00:00:24.601 --> 00:00:29.171
with us today, we were able to go ahead
and convince her to show up for storytime.

11
00:00:29.171 --> 00:00:30.441
I mean testing time.

12
00:00:30.441 --> 00:00:34.397
>> Yeah, that's why I showed up because
you were gonna make a mess of that

13
00:00:34.397 --> 00:00:35.212
one, right?

14
00:00:35.212 --> 00:00:38.956
[LAUGH]
>> Great, great, I couldn't help myself,

15
00:00:38.956 --> 00:00:41.328
story telling and circle time.

16
00:00:41.328 --> 00:00:44.663
I have kids, so that's,
my mind travels there, I can't help it Jo.

17
00:00:44.663 --> 00:00:46.443
>> Look, I did that deliberately.

18
00:00:46.443 --> 00:00:48.935
>> [LAUGH] I'm sorry, but
I did that deliberately, right?

19
00:00:48.935 --> 00:00:52.180
[LAUGH] Yeah, we're gonna be testing for
storytelling.

20
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:55.163
>> Okay, so in Agile stories.

21
00:00:55.163 --> 00:00:56.710
We know what stories are, right?

22
00:00:56.710 --> 00:00:57.524
>> Right.

23
00:00:57.524 --> 00:00:59.198
>> So what is the telling part of it?

24
00:00:59.198 --> 00:01:00.213
How does that work together?

25
00:01:00.213 --> 00:01:01.442
>> Well, right, okay.

26
00:01:01.442 --> 00:01:06.428
So stories traditionally start off
with once upon a time, I guess, yeah.

27
00:01:06.428 --> 00:01:10.663
They usually end up with
happily ever after.

28
00:01:10.663 --> 00:01:13.065
I know, maybe not,
it depends what stories you read.

29
00:01:13.065 --> 00:01:14.374
Not all the stories I read.

30
00:01:14.374 --> 00:01:18.299
But anyway, as far as Agile is concerned,

31
00:01:18.299 --> 00:01:22.450
as far as product
development is concerned.

32
00:01:22.450 --> 00:01:27.573
We use user stories and
user stories will tell us what our

33
00:01:27.573 --> 00:01:33.029
users want to see for
a particular piece of functionality.

34
00:01:33.029 --> 00:01:37.714
Story telling is actually
expanding on that user story.

35
00:01:37.714 --> 00:01:41.519
So let's take a look at,
I've got an example here over user story.

36
00:01:41.519 --> 00:01:44.755
Bear in mind that we
are on testing mode here.

37
00:01:44.755 --> 00:01:47.190
So, here is the user story.

38
00:01:47.190 --> 00:01:50.347
And a user story will always
start off with as a and

39
00:01:50.347 --> 00:01:54.507
then you define the customer and
then, you describe the need and

40
00:01:54.507 --> 00:01:58.374
then you'll say, so
that I have money where I need it to be.

41
00:01:58.374 --> 00:02:00.280
Okay, so you describe the need and

42
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:03.255
then you describe what it is
you want the result to be.

43
00:02:03.255 --> 00:02:09.261
So as a customer, I need to transfer
money, so that it's where it needs to be.

44
00:02:09.261 --> 00:02:10.046
>> Right.

45
00:02:10.046 --> 00:02:14.330
>> Now we've looked at testing quadrants
in a previous episode and in our last

46
00:02:14.330 --> 00:02:18.965
episode, we looked at the test driven
development of acceptance tested, etc.

47
00:02:18.965 --> 00:02:23.412
And now we're gonna look
further at the storytelling and

48
00:02:23.412 --> 00:02:29.538
how all of these types of tests fit in
with, you might think of it as scenarios.

49
00:02:29.538 --> 00:02:33.515
As a bank customer,
I need to transfer money, so

50
00:02:33.515 --> 00:02:36.916
that I've got money where it needs to be.

51
00:02:36.916 --> 00:02:41.241
Just think about now then the types
of transfers that there are.

52
00:02:41.241 --> 00:02:45.657
So you might want to
schedule a future transfer.

53
00:02:45.657 --> 00:02:49.196
You might want to review
your scheduled transfers.

54
00:02:49.196 --> 00:02:52.763
You might want to schedule
an immediate transfer.

55
00:02:52.763 --> 00:02:56.793
You might want to cancel a transfer,
your transfer might be between internal

56
00:02:56.793 --> 00:02:59.533
accounts or
it might be between external accounts.

57
00:02:59.533 --> 00:03:04.500
You might want to ensure
what you definitely want to

58
00:03:04.500 --> 00:03:09.594
ensure that it's being completed,
right, yeah.

59
00:03:09.594 --> 00:03:13.261
But you might want it on a statement or
you might not want it on a statement.

60
00:03:13.261 --> 00:03:14.654
You might want it on an email.

61
00:03:14.654 --> 00:03:16.444
Now, I'm not too sure about you.

62
00:03:16.444 --> 00:03:19.484
But when I transfer money
between my accounts,

63
00:03:19.484 --> 00:03:22.227
I don't want an email
every time I do that.

64
00:03:22.227 --> 00:03:24.624
I just want a little pop up to say,
hey, that's been done.

65
00:03:24.624 --> 00:03:26.750
That's great.

66
00:03:26.750 --> 00:03:28.135
What we've done,

67
00:03:28.135 --> 00:03:33.688
is we've taken the actual user story
which is right at the beginning there.

68
00:03:33.688 --> 00:03:36.175
As the bank customer or so
right in the middle of the screen.

69
00:03:36.175 --> 00:03:40.000
I need to transfer money
between my accounts, so

70
00:03:40.000 --> 00:03:44.119
that I can validate an icon,
reconcile my records.

71
00:03:44.119 --> 00:03:46.393
So I've got money where I need it to be.

72
00:03:46.393 --> 00:03:48.482
This is my story.

73
00:03:48.482 --> 00:03:54.290
What I've got here though,
is what I want to call my epic story.

74
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:56.984
And do you remember
what an epic story was?

75
00:03:56.984 --> 00:03:59.640
It wasn't just a great story.

76
00:03:59.640 --> 00:04:01.379
>> It was an epic story.

77
00:04:01.379 --> 00:04:04.782
Let me tell you about it, Jo.

78
00:04:04.782 --> 00:04:07.866
A bundle or
compilation of multiple stories.

79
00:04:07.866 --> 00:04:08.988
>> Right.

80
00:04:08.988 --> 00:04:11.979
So it could be a compilation
of multiple story, so

81
00:04:11.979 --> 00:04:15.413
it could be various scenarios
on exactly the same story.

82
00:04:15.413 --> 00:04:15.969
>> Okay.

83
00:04:15.969 --> 00:04:20.432
>> So what you've got here and
this is why we call this story telling,

84
00:04:20.432 --> 00:04:24.657
what you've got here is basically
you've got an epic story but

85
00:04:24.657 --> 00:04:28.343
they're all, well,
they're all on the same thing.

86
00:04:28.343 --> 00:04:32.227
So they're all stories that
are relating to exactly the same theme.

87
00:04:32.227 --> 00:04:37.142
Which is this original theme of
transferring money between accounts.

88
00:04:37.142 --> 00:04:41.227
So that would be the title
of my epic story.

89
00:04:41.227 --> 00:04:43.752
My storytelling looks at all the, well,

90
00:04:43.752 --> 00:04:46.649
you might want to thinks
of them as sub stories.

91
00:04:46.649 --> 00:04:48.576
That's not we call them
in our job by the way.

92
00:04:48.576 --> 00:04:49.963
We just call them individual stories.

93
00:04:49.963 --> 00:04:53.654
But you might want to think of them
as sub stories to that epic story.

94
00:04:53.654 --> 00:04:57.701
So what you have is one
story right infront of you.

95
00:04:57.701 --> 00:05:01.383
And that is it's about customer and I need
to transfer money between my accounts.

96
00:05:01.383 --> 00:05:03.512
So I've got money where I need it to be.

97
00:05:03.512 --> 00:05:07.680
And then I've got all of these sub
stories scheduled in a future transfer,

98
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:09.879
reviewing a schedule transfer, etc.

99
00:05:12.959 --> 00:05:18.822
Now, we're in development right now and
we're also gonna focus purely on testing.

100
00:05:18.822 --> 00:05:22.437
But I've got a couple of
things that I wanna say.

101
00:05:22.437 --> 00:05:25.300
How long is an iteration or sprint?

102
00:05:25.300 --> 00:05:26.180
>> One to four weeks.

103
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:27.513
>> One to four weeks, okay.

104
00:05:27.513 --> 00:05:31.316
So, what we've got right in front
of us now is we've got five?

105
00:05:31.316 --> 00:05:32.104
Five stories.

106
00:05:32.104 --> 00:05:33.638
>> One, two, three, four, five, yeah.

107
00:05:33.638 --> 00:05:35.112
>> Five sort of sub-stories, right?
>> Yeah, yeah.

108
00:05:35.112 --> 00:05:36.291
[LAUGH]
>> I can count, yay.

109
00:05:36.291 --> 00:05:36.933
[LAUGH]
>> It's all right,

110
00:05:36.933 --> 00:05:37.656
I had to do that as well.

111
00:05:37.656 --> 00:05:39.906
That's why I-
>> Storytime and one, two, three.

112
00:05:39.906 --> 00:05:43.588
>> That's why I was looking at it,
going [LAUGH] a little bit cross eyed.

113
00:05:43.588 --> 00:05:46.154
But yeah, so we got five stories there.

114
00:05:46.154 --> 00:05:53.321
Do you think that we want to put each
one of these into one iteration?

115
00:05:53.321 --> 00:05:54.961
Do we put them all in one iteration?

116
00:05:54.961 --> 00:05:58.705
>> No, all right, at least I wouldn't and
I would just be you.

117
00:05:58.705 --> 00:06:01.713
Dragging things out,
you've got other work to do.

118
00:06:01.713 --> 00:06:06.834
>> But are you gonna release these then,
separately to your customers?

119
00:06:06.834 --> 00:06:10.238
>> Hmm, review scheduled transfers.

120
00:06:10.238 --> 00:06:12.633
Released them separately,
I'm gonna say no.

121
00:06:12.633 --> 00:06:14.153
I wanna see it all.

353

00:19:19.520 --> 00:19:22.082

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.

up to four weeks per iteration.

fundamentals class and

00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:42.238

71
00:03:42.238 --> 00:03:45.860

78

The reason the testing gets cut is

79

And then what happens is, and this is
where we end up, in a situation where, and

I know and in fact, Justin and
I have done a look in episode.

You'll see an episode on our course
library about the difference between

00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:32.480
And we looked at this because there's

a perception of two
different teams within IT.

There's the perception of
having the development team.

And pick up the pieces

90

If we don't do adequate testing
here in the project side,

>> Yeah, I was gonna say that, I needed to

00:05:04.592 --> 00:05:11.941
But yeah, I mean, we end up handing over
a complete mess to our operations guys.

94
00:05:11.941 --> 00:05:14.808
And so the service management guys

95
00:05:14.808 --> 00:05:15.447
>> Right.

96
00:05:15.447 --> 00:05:19.910
>> And this is where we end up with
that perception of two different teams.

97
00:05:19.910 --> 00:05:22.080
And this is where we end
up with a contention.

98
00:05:22.080 --> 00:05:24.522
And with all of the argument
that goes along with it,

99
00:05:24.522 --> 00:05:26.631
where the operations guys are saying, hey,

100
00:05:26.631 --> 00:05:30.317
you're just throwing products over
the fence and then abandoning us with it.

101
00:05:30.317 --> 00:05:33.475
And the project team is saying, well,

102
00:05:33.475 --> 00:05:37.793
you need to be doing this,
you need to be fixing this.

103
00:05:37.793 --> 00:05:41.671
The fact is that all of this could be
ironed out if we've got successful

104
00:05:41.671 --> 00:05:42.720
testing.

105
00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:44.222
So we have to ensure.

106
00:05:44.222 --> 00:05:49.225
It's our responsibility really, to ensure
that if you're gonna develop a product,

00:05:49.225 --> 00:05:52.510
well, you gotta make sure it works, right?

108
00:05:52.510 --> 00:05:56.342
I mean, it doesn't make sense to

109
00:05:56.342 --> 00:05:58.365
But you're right,
everybody is under pressure.

110

And so testing is the first
thing that gets moved.

111
00:06:02.350 --> 00:06:06.820
And as you said, people just don't
realize that actually, this is important.

112
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:07.818
>> Right.

113
00:06:07.818 --> 00:06:11.120
>> And when you're under pressure you just
think to yourself, I'm just gonna develop

00:06:11.120 --> 00:06:14.890
this particular product and I'm just gonna

115
00:06:14.890 --> 00:06:18.084
How many times though,
in a real world experience,

116

ignoring sort of in our own organizations,
how many times out there in the market

00:06:23.022 --> 00:06:27.380
place have manufacturers of software

00:06:40.632 --> 00:06:42.130

00:06:42.130 --> 00:06:45.224
I mean, you look at some

they even blow up on you because of-

>> So I mean, it's across the board here.

00:06:51.093 --> 00:06:55.652
>> Yeah, yeah, it is, and

00:07:17.980 --> 00:07:21.170

00:07:29.232 --> 00:07:33.608

00:07:33.608 --> 00:07:37.709

00:07:53.510 --> 00:07:54.044

00:07:54.044 --> 00:07:57.760

00:07:59.051 --> 00:08:02.322

145
00:08:02.322 --> 00:08:06.196
And when you deliver a substandard
product you lose your costumer loyalty,

146
00:08:06.196 --> 00:08:10.070

you're not delivering quality and

147
00:08:10.070 --> 00:08:12.010

163

00:09:22.160 --> 00:09:25.940
So in terms of the testing then,
the product owner

00:09:25.940 --> 00:09:29.198

gonna sign off on the testing,

167
00:09:29.198 --> 00:09:34.460
whereas the scrum master is the person
that's going to be managing the team

168
00:09:34.460 --> 00:09:38.260
to make sure that everybody
is involved in the testing.

169
00:09:38.260 --> 00:09:43.130
So the team that's doing the testing,
the scrum master is going

170
00:09:43.130 --> 00:09:48.020
to be involved in ensuring
that everybody is, you know,

171
00:09:48.020 --> 00:09:51.740
undertaking their responsibilities and
the test didn't happen.

172
00:09:51.740 --> 00:09:56.350
Whereas the product owner is responsible
for the content of the testing.

173
00:09:56.350 --> 00:10:00.400
So the product owner will
assume that responsibility.

174
00:10:00.400 --> 00:10:02.530
It's part of their responsibility.

175
00:10:02.530 --> 00:10:04.674
So if you look at the next page,

176
00:10:04.674 --> 00:10:10.790
the product owner is thinking about what's
acceptable, what is my acceptance level?

177
00:10:10.790 --> 00:10:12.779
You know,
what are my customer requirements?

178
00:10:12.779 --> 00:10:16.100
What is it exactly that
I should be delivering?

179
00:10:16.100 --> 00:10:21.350
And so the customers,
the product owner is responsible for

180
00:10:21.350 --> 00:10:25.620
the user stories, making sure
that we meet in the user stories.

181
00:10:25.620 --> 00:10:30.430
And the product owner is responsible for
ensuring that, you know, we test and

182
00:10:30.430 --> 00:10:34.330
there are no errors and
that it delivers the requirements, but

183
00:10:34.330 --> 00:10:37.920
also that we're doing the behavior
driven testing as well.

184
00:10:37.920 --> 00:10:40.870
You know the scenario based, the what if.

185
00:10:40.870 --> 00:10:43.870
If I do it like this
then what will happen?

186
00:10:43.870 --> 00:10:47.360
So the product owner takes
all of that ownership.

187
00:10:47.360 --> 00:10:53.190
And then some projects depending
on the scale of the project.

188
00:10:53.190 --> 00:10:56.100
You may also have a test manager.

189
00:10:57.470 --> 00:11:00.050
Dependent on this scale.

190
00:11:00.050 --> 00:11:04.450
Now what we've got here,
is you've got in this particular example,

191
00:11:04.450 --> 00:11:07.480
you've got a very,
very large project team.

192
00:11:07.480 --> 00:11:11.970
And in a large project team,
we've got here in our Agile Team there,

193
00:11:11.970 --> 00:11:16.580
you've got a scrum master who may be
reporting into a project manager.

194
00:11:16.580 --> 00:11:21.180
You've got developers who may
be on a normal day-to-day basis.

195
00:11:21.180 --> 00:11:24.950
Reporting into the development manager and
then you've got a tester and

196
00:11:24.950 --> 00:11:26.990
a test manager.

197
00:11:26.990 --> 00:11:32.010
This is a large scale
organization here and of course,

198
00:11:32.010 --> 00:11:36.790
remember we work collaboratively
in an Agile Team so

199
00:11:36.790 --> 00:11:41.210
whilst these roles may be
defined in a large organization.

200
00:11:41.210 --> 00:11:45.520
It may not necessarily be defined
we're working collaboratively and so

201
00:11:45.520 --> 00:11:49.370
it may be that you take responsibility for
testing in one particular piece of

202
00:11:49.370 --> 00:11:53.900
functionality or one particular user
story and I'll take responsibility for

203
00:11:53.900 --> 00:11:55.790
testing something else, okay?

204
00:11:55.790 --> 00:11:58.680
Remember, we're working collaboratively.

205
00:11:58.680 --> 00:12:02.530
But testing is the huge
part of the project.

206
00:12:02.530 --> 00:12:08.220
It's a huge part of our, you know, of our
project management, of our methodology.

207
00:12:10.130 --> 00:12:14.860
So this particular slide, I just wanna us
to look really at planning for our test.

208
00:12:14.860 --> 00:12:18.050
And you'll see that in
the right here we plan for

209
00:12:18.050 --> 00:12:21.630

when we initiate a project.

210
00:12:22.900 --> 00:12:25.460
I'm gonna go back to what I was
saying just a little while ago.

211
00:12:25.460 --> 00:12:28.926
When we initiate a project,

00:24:59.910 --> 00:25:02.050
And how do they need to see it?

445
00:25:02.050 --> 00:25:05.860
Does it need to be a formal report?

446
00:25:05.860 --> 00:25:10.320
Or could it be something that's in a daily
standup, just feedback from a daily

447
00:25:10.320 --> 00:25:15.510
standup or what we call the information
radiators or Kanban board for instance?

448
00:25:15.510 --> 00:25:19.660
Is it just the case of moving a post-it
note from one position to another?

449
00:25:19.660 --> 00:25:22.670
Or does it have to be a formal report?

450
00:25:22.670 --> 00:25:24.480
It really depends on who is going to,

451
00:25:24.480 --> 00:25:28.630
which is why I say think of the audience
because the language that you use and

452
00:25:28.630 --> 00:25:35.290
the amount or the depth of the report is
really dependent on who your audience is.

453
00:25:35.290 --> 00:25:37.490
But remember you're remaining efficient

454
00:25:38.530 --> 00:25:41.740
to think about the medium
that you're going to use.

455
00:25:41.740 --> 00:25:45.180
And it's the same with the metrics
from our testing as well,

456
00:25:45.180 --> 00:25:48.440
think about what you're recording and

457
00:25:48.440 --> 00:25:54.830
at what point in time do you acknowledge
that actually something has been done.

458
00:25:54.830 --> 00:25:58.262
What I want to see is my defect backlog,
well,

459
00:25:58.262 --> 00:26:01.961
I want to see it down to zero,
that's my backlog.

460
00:26:01.961 --> 00:26:06.562
But I want to see the progress of my test,
and what that's doing there on

461
00:26:06.562 --> 00:26:10.477
the bottom sorta graph there
is the programs should really,

462
00:26:10.477 --> 00:26:16.370
what's left to do should be diminishing
as we move through each iteration.

463
00:26:16.370 --> 00:26:21.090
Ultimately what I want to see
is I want to see progression.

464
00:26:21.090 --> 00:26:24.513
I want to see that testing is progressing,

465
00:26:24.513 --> 00:26:28.412
I want to see the number
of defects decreasing and

466
00:26:28.412 --> 00:26:33.450
I want to see that we get to
a position where we make a decision for

467
00:26:33.450 --> 00:26:39.750
each iteration based on whether the
functionality has passed the test or not.

468
00:26:39.750 --> 00:26:41.440
It's as simple as that.

469
00:26:42.670 --> 00:26:46.040
We do not decide to release if
we haven't done any testing or

470
00:26:46.040 --> 00:26:48.370
if we haven't passed the testing.

471
00:26:48.370 --> 00:26:49.300
>> That's a big point.

472
00:26:49.300 --> 00:26:51.260
It's like, hey, I did all my testing, but

473
00:26:51.260 --> 00:26:56.520
then if it fails,
I can check it off my box.

474
00:26:56.520 --> 00:26:57.950
>> Right, yeah, yeah.

475
00:26:57.950 --> 00:27:01.170
And that's the other thing is just cuz
you've done the test doesn't mean you're

476
00:27:01.170 --> 00:27:03.220
successful at doing the test.

477
00:27:03.220 --> 00:27:07.840
[LAUGH] You've got to make sure
you do the test and that it works.

478
00:27:07.840 --> 00:27:09.390
That's when you decide to release.

479
00:27:11.390 --> 00:27:16.320
And don't forget that at every iteration,

480
00:27:16.320 --> 00:27:20.870
well, it's a change to how
things were previously.

481
00:27:20.870 --> 00:27:27.000
And so even with our testing, well-
>> We're testing iteratively?

482
00:27:27.000 --> 00:27:29.030
>> We're testing iteratively, yes.

483
00:27:29.030 --> 00:27:31.640
But even with our testing we
can improve on our testing.

484
00:27:31.640 --> 00:27:34.360
So maybe with one iteration
we may test manually and

485
00:27:34.360 --> 00:27:38.920
then with the next iteration,
we test automatically for instance.

486
00:27:38.920 --> 00:27:43.270
Yes, so we always want to ensure
that we work in efficiently.

487
00:27:43.270 --> 00:27:48.399
Until we always wanna make
sure that our testing improve.

488
00:27:48.399 --> 00:27:53.071
So if I now automate my test and while
I've done it manually this first time,

489
00:27:53.071 --> 00:27:57.524
my next situation I'm gonna automate and
then I can use that test to apply

490
00:27:57.524 --> 00:28:01.977
that to other iterations both in the
future and maybe if I wanna go back and

491
00:28:01.977 --> 00:28:06.504
test any previous functionality
because maybe something didn't work,

492
00:28:06.504 --> 00:28:08.640
then I can use that, as well.

493
00:28:08.640 --> 00:28:09.140
We learn.

494
00:28:10.650 --> 00:28:15.370
And that's really what I'm gonna say about
testing and testing with each situation.

495
00:28:15.370 --> 00:28:17.530
Is with each situation, we learn.

496
00:28:19.030 --> 00:28:22.570
We should be learning
from previous situations,

497
00:28:22.570 --> 00:28:27.160
we should be learning from what
we did in the past, always.

498
00:28:28.610 --> 00:28:33.930
So testing is a huge part
of the project itself.

499
00:28:33.930 --> 00:28:38.470
But testing should also be
done before we make a decision

500
00:28:38.470 --> 00:28:43.620

501
00:28:43.620 --> 00:28:47.810
And so in our next episode, we're
actually going to look then the delivery

00:28:47.810 --> 00:28:50.560
of that particular release so
that iteration.

503
00:28:50.560 --> 00:28:51.910
>> Did you say deliviries, Jo?

504
00:28:51.910 --> 00:28:55.800
You know I love deliveries, my favorite

505
00:28:55.800 --> 00:28:58.470
So I'm really looking
forward to this next show.

506
00:28:58.470 --> 00:29:01.680
Hopefully, you guys we'll join us

507
00:29:01.680 --> 00:29:03.310
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

00:29:03.310 --> 00:29:04.285

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Agile project management testing, the techniques, and the roles and responsibilities associated with Agile testing. Throughout the episodes we recap over Agile basics and journey through testing quadrants, categories, and timing.  
All accompanying course materials are downloadable and also provide suggestions for testing environments.

>> Yes.

>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

You're baseline for the walking,

as is picture so

If you don't take a baseline,

then the first measurement that

So our first measurement then
